elements.content: The reactions of 2-(4-pyridyl) thiazole-4-carboxylic acid (Hptca) and CuCl2·6H2O have led to a novel 3D mixed-valence, four-copper-center, metal–organic framework (MOF) [Cu8Cl2(ptca)10·17H2O] n (1). The topology analysis using ToposPro software package for 1 resulted in three chain-based topology types of sra (42, 63, 8), pcu (412, 63), and dia (66) via choosing corresponding connection atoms as central atoms. The study indicates that connection atoms associated directly with multiple coordination centers are applicable to act as central atoms. This unique topology analysis approach is conceptually different from the current analytical methods which use node atoms as central atoms. In addition, complex 1 exhibits significant selective adsorption of CO2 over N2. This study provides a great example of the topological analysis of MOFs with multiple coordination centers.

elements.content: The topology analysis for a 3D four-coordination-center framework (MOF) by ToposPro resulted in three chain-based topology types, sra (42, 63, 8), pcu (412, 63), and dia (66), via choosing corresponding connection atoms/nonmetal atoms as central atoms.

elements.content: Metal–organic frameworks (MOFs) have been rapidly developed in recent years because of their potential applications as functional materials and fascinating structures. The topological analysis of MOFs still plays a critical role in structural characterization of the MOFs because it contributes not only to the understanding of the structure construction but also to an instructive role in the rational design of MOFs with desirable properties. Program package ToposPro serves as a substantial tool in topology analysis. During the analysis process, the central atom selection step is considered to be the most important process for determining the final topological classification. To date, the topological analysis that approaches the underlying nets with structure unit nodes can be roughly divided using three methods. The first method is to set the structure units as nodes and then concentrate the nodes to pseudoatoms by cutting off some covalent bonds and establishing new connections using XP software. The pseudoatoms as central atoms are then used in the topological analysis through ToposPro. In this way, the nodes of the resulting topology are consistent with the selected central atoms and usually the preset structural units. The second method is to weaken certain covalent bonds into hydrogen bonds by employing procedure settings in ToposPro and then selecting the metal atoms as central atoms to carry out the topology analysis. The third method is to obtain the topology type by selecting metal ions alone as central atoms in the process of running the default settings of ToposPro and then finding the structural unit node and the connections in the network. Notably, all three methods select the central atoms based on the node atom, such as pseudoatoms and metal ions. Therefore, methods 1 and 2 are applicable to analyzing topologies with multimetal clusters, dual cores, and multidentate ligand, while the last method is more suitable for topology with nodes of metal ions. However, because of the diversity of composition and the complexity of the MOFs’ structure, it is difficult to yield the classical topology type with topology analysis and thereby to produce new topology types. Hence, it is necessary to accumulate topology analysis experience and develop new approaches for multicoordination center MOFs.
elements.clean_text:
Introduction

Metal-organic frameworks (MOFs) have been rapidly developed in recent years because of their potential applications as functional materials and fascinating structures. The topological analysis of MOFs still plays a critical role in structural characterization of the MOFs because it contributes not only to the understanding of the structure construction but also to an instructive role in the rational design of MOFs with desirable properties. Program package ToposPro serves as a substantial tool in topology analysis. During the analysis process, the central atom selection step is considered to be the most important process for determining the final topological classification. To date, the topological analysis that approaches the underlying nets with structure unit nodes can be roughly divided using three methods. The first method is to set the structure units as nodes and then concentrate the nodes to pseudoatoms by cutting off some covalent bonds and establishing new connections using XP software. The pseudoatoms as central atoms are then used in the topological analysis through ToposPro. In this way, the nodes of the resulting topology are consistent with the selected central atoms and usually the preset structural units. The second method is to weaken certain covalent bonds into hydrogen bonds by employing procedure settings in ToposPro and then selecting the metal atoms as central atoms to carry out the topology analysis. The third method is to obtain the topology type by selecting metal ions alone as central atoms in the process of running the default settings of ToposPro and then finding the structural unit node and the connections in the network. Notably, all three methods select the central atoms based on the node atom, such as pseudoatoms and metal ions. Therefore, methods 1 and 2 are applicable to analyzing topologies with multimetal clusters, dual cores, and multidentate ligand, while the last method is more suitable for topology with nodes of metal ions. However, because of the diversity of composition and the complexity of the MOFs' structure, it is difficult to yield the classical topology type with topology analysis and thereby to produce new topology types. Hence, it is necessary to accumulate topology analysis experience and develop new approaches for multicoordination center MOFs.

elements.content: Mixed-valence CuI/CuII coordination polymers (CPs) are usually obtained through the metal in situ reaction route from CuII or CuI salt in the literature. Ligand selection for oxidizing/reducing CuI/CuII to CuII/CuI under the desired synthesis conditions needs to be optimized. Therefore, azo-based ligands as an alternative pathway to producing CuI/CuII MOFs has been employed. In addition, counterion Cl– can be incorporated as an essential component leading to high structural complexity and interesting properties in previous cases. Given all of this, 2-(4-pyridyl) thiazole-4-carboxylic acid (HL) and CuCl2·6H2O were chosen to construct mixed-valence CuI/CuII MOF. Although HL has been used to synthesize MOFs before, the redox reaction of the ligand with metal atoms has not yet been reported. Herein, one novel 3D mixed-valent CuI/CuII complex, [Cu4ClL5·5H2O] n (1), was successfully synthesized. The MOF owns multicoordination centers and multiple coordination modes of the ligand, contributing an unprecedented complicated structural feature and providing extraordinary fodder for investigating the multipath, multitype topological analysis. The analysis results in three different classical topologies via choosing various corresponding connection atoms as the central atoms via ToposPro software.

elements.content: All commercially available chemicals and solvents are reagent grade and were used as received without further purification. Powder elemental analysis (C, H, and N) was performed on a Vario EL III elemental analyzer. X-ray diffraction (PXRD) patterns were recorded on a Bruker D8 Advance diffractometer (Cu Kα). FTIR spectra were recorded in the range of 400–4000 cm–1 on a Bruker Vector 22 FTIR spectrophotometer using KBr pellets. X-ray photoelectron spectroscopy (XPS) was recorded on UlVAC-PHI PHI 5000 Versa Probe photoelectron spectrograph. Thermal gravimetric analysis was performed under N2 using a NETZSCH TG 209 system.
elements.clean_text:
Experimental Section

Materials and Methods

All commercially available chemicals and solvents are reagent grade and were used as received without further purification. Powder elemental analysis (C, H, and N) was performed on a Vario EL III elemental analyzer. X-ray diffraction (PXRD) patterns were recorded on a Bruker D8 Advance diffractometer (Cu Kα). FTIR spectra were recorded in the range of 400-4000 cm-1 on a Bruker Vector 22 FTIR spectrophotometer using KBr pellets. X-ray photoelectron spectroscopy (XPS) was recorded on UlVAC-PHI PHI 5000 Versa Probe photoelectron spectrograph. Thermal gravimetric analysis was performed under N2 using a NETZSCH TG 209 system.

elements.content: Diffraction data of 1 was collected on a Bruker Smart Apex II CCD with a graphite monochromated Mo Kα radiation source (λ = 0.71073 Å) in ω scan mode at 296(2) K. The diffraction data were integrated by using the SAINT program, which was also used for the intensity corrections for the Lorentz and polarization effects. Semiempirical absorption corrections were applied using the SADABS program. The structure was solved by direct methods using SHELXS-97, and all of the non-hydrogen atoms were refined on F 2 by full-matrix least-squares procedures with SHELXL-97. Hydrogen atoms, except those of water molecules, were generated geometrically and refined isotropically using the riding model. Attempts to locate and model the highly disordered solvent molecules in the pores were unsuccessful. Therefore, the SQUEEZE routine of PLATON was used to remove the diffraction contribution from guests to produce a set of solvent-free diffraction intensities. The formula was designated from the electrons resulting from the SQUEEZE routine and the experimental results (CIF). The details of the crystal parameters, data collection, and refinements for 1 are summarized in . Selected bond lengths and angles for 1 are collected in Table S1.
elements.clean_text:
Crystal Structure Determination

Diffraction data of 1 was collected on a Bruker Smart Apex II CCD with a graphite monochromated Mo Kα radiation source (λ = 0.71073 Å) in ω scan mode at 296(2) K. The diffraction data were integrated by using the SAINT program, which was also used for the intensity corrections for the Lorentz and polarization effects. Semiempirical absorption corrections were applied using the SADABS program. The structure was solved by direct methods using SHELXS-97, and all of the non-hydrogen atoms were refined on F 2 by full-matrix least-squares procedures with SHELXL-97. Hydrogen atoms, except those of water molecules, were generated geometrically and refined isotropically using the riding model. Attempts to locate and model the highly disordered solvent molecules in the pores were unsuccessful. Therefore, the SQUEEZE routine of PLATON was used to remove the diffraction contribution from guests to produce a set of solvent-free diffraction intensities. The formula was designated from the electrons resulting from the SQUEEZE routine and the experimental results (CIF). The details of the crystal parameters, data collection, and refinements for 1 are summarized in . Selected bond lengths and angles for 1 are collected in Table S1.

elements.clean_text:
Synthesis of Complex 1 

CuCl2 ⋅2H2O (17.0 mg, 0.1 mmol), Hptca (20.6 mg, 0.1 mmol), NaOH solution ( 4.0 mL, 0.025 mol⋅L-1), and water (4.0 mL) were added to a 10.0 mL Teflon-lined stainless steel autoclave. It was held at 120 °C for 2 days. After it cooled to room temperature, yellow block crystals of complex 1 were obtained in 58% yield. The resulting solution had a pH value of 7. Anal. Calcd for C90H84Cl2N20O7S10Cu8: C, 36.80; H, 2.88; N, 9.54%. Found: C, 36.77; H, 2.71; N, 9.49%. IR (KBr pellet, cm-1): 3448 (s), 1610 (s), 1536 (m), 1394 (s), 1102 (w), 990 (w), 854 (w), 786 (m), 673 (m).

elements.content: Single-crystal X-ray diffraction analysis reveals that the asymmetric unit of 1 contains bivalent Cu1 and Cu2 and monovalent Cu3 and Cu4 atoms, five L ligands, and one Cl1 bridge (a and S1). In complex 1, the L ligands display three kinds of coordination patterns, μ2-L-k2-N:O (μ2-L), μ2-L-k3-N:N′,O (μ2-L′), and μ3-L-k4-N:N′,O:O (μ3-L) (Figure S2). Each Cu1 center is five coordinated by carboxyl O3 and thiazolyl N3 from μ2-L′ in a chelated pattern, one carboxyl O5 from μ2-L, and one pyridyl N2 from μ3-L as well as a Cl1 atom. The coordination environment around the Cu1 atom manifests a distorted {CuN2O2Cl} square-pyramidal geometry. The five-coordinate Cu2 atom exhibits distorted {CuN2O3} square-pyramidal geometry and is doubly chelated by O7, N7 from μ2-L′ and O1, and N1 from μ3-L ligands in the cis configuration, while the remaining coordination site is occupied by the O9 atom from the μ2-L ligand. Moreover, the monovalent Cu3 and Cu4 ions display different {CuN2Cl} and {AgN2O} planar trianglar geometry, respectively. Cu3 is surrounded by pyridyl N6 of μ2-L′ and N8 of the μ2-L atoms and the Cl1 atom. The coordination sphere of the Cu4 center is completed by N4 of μ2-L′ and N10 of μ2-L and the carboxyl O1 atom of μ3-L. Cu1, Cu2, Cu3, and Cu4 are linked by two μ2-L and two μ2-L′ ligands into a 0D structural unit [Cu4L4]. It links to μ3-L by O1–Cu2, forming a centrosymmetric secondary building unit (SBU) of [Cu4L5]. It is worth noting that there are levorotatory and dextrorotatory [Cu4L5] groups in 1 (a). L/R-[Cu4L5] doubly links to homochiral L/R-[Cu4L5] based on two O1 atoms’ coordination (Cu2–O1–Cu4) and doubly connects to heterochiral R/L-[Cu4L5] by relying on two pyridyl N2 coordination (N2–Cu1) from two μ3-L. Therefore, the adjacent SBUs are connected to form a 1D thick-belt-shaped [Cu4L5] n chain extending along the [0.5 0 0.5] direction (b). The angle between the two planes of either homochiral L- and L- or R- and R-[Cu4L5] is 45°. The infinite 1D chains are interconnected by μ2-Cl1 (Cu1–Cl1–Cu3), giving rise to a 3D framework (c). The detailed information for chain connections becomes quite complicated as a result of the chirality and horizontal rotation of SBUs within the chain, which could be recognized by a topology study. In addition, the 1D channels with an average diameter of 9.5 Å in 1 stack up by opening rings (d,e). The void volume of 1 was estimated to be 17.6% using PLATON. Nitrogen and chlorine atoms are exposed to the surface of the channel, which may have a significant effect on the gas adsorption properties.
elements.clean_text:
Results and Discussion

Structural Description of 1 

Single-crystal X-ray diffraction analysis reveals that the asymmetric unit of 1 contains bivalent Cu1 and Cu2 and monovalent Cu3 and Cu4 atoms, five L ligands, and one Cl1 bridge (a and S1). In complex 1, the L ligands display three kinds of coordination patterns, μ2-L-k2-N:O (μ2-L), μ2-L-k3-N:N',O (μ2-L'), and μ3-L-k4-N:N',O:O (μ3-L) (Figure S2). Each Cu1 center is five coordinated by carboxyl O3 and thiazolyl N3 from μ2-L' in a chelated pattern, one carboxyl O5 from μ2-L, and one pyridyl N2 from μ3-L as well as a Cl1 atom. The coordination environment around the Cu1 atom manifests a distorted {CuN2O2Cl} square-pyramidal geometry. The five-coordinate Cu2 atom exhibits distorted {CuN2O3} square-pyramidal geometry and is doubly chelated by O7, N7 from μ2-L' and O1, and N1 from μ3-L ligands in the cis configuration, while the remaining coordination site is occupied by the O9 atom from the μ2-L ligand. Moreover, the monovalent Cu3 and Cu4 ions display different {CuN2Cl} and {AgN2O} planar trianglar geometry, respectively. Cu3 is surrounded by pyridyl N6 of μ2-L' and N8 of the μ2-L atoms and the Cl1 atom. The coordination sphere of the Cu4 center is completed by N4 of μ2-L' and N10 of μ2-L and the carboxyl O1 atom of μ3-L. Cu1, Cu2, Cu3, and Cu4 are linked by two μ2-L and two μ2-L' ligands into a 0D structural unit [Cu4L4]. It links to μ3-L by O1-Cu2, forming a centrosymmetric secondary building unit (SBU) of [Cu4L5]. It is worth noting that there are levorotatory and dextrorotatory [Cu4L5] groups in 1 (a). L/R-[Cu4L5] doubly links to homochiral L/R-[Cu4L5] based on two O1 atoms' coordination (Cu2-O1-Cu4) and doubly connects to heterochiral R/L-[Cu4L5] by relying on two pyridyl N2 coordination (N2-Cu1) from two μ3-L. Therefore, the adjacent SBUs are connected to form a 1D thick-belt-shaped [Cu4L5] n  chain extending along the [0.5 0 0.5] direction (b). The angle between the two planes of either homochiral L- and L- or R- and R-[Cu4L5] is 45°. The infinite 1D chains are interconnected by μ2-Cl1 (Cu1-Cl1-Cu3), giving rise to a 3D framework (c). The detailed information for chain connections becomes quite complicated as a result of the chirality and horizontal rotation of SBUs within the chain, which could be recognized by a topology study. In addition, the 1D channels with an average diameter of 9.5 Å in 1 stack up by opening rings (d,e). The void volume of 1 was estimated to be 17.6% using PLATON. Nitrogen and chlorine atoms are exposed to the surface of the channel, which may have a significant effect on the gas adsorption properties.

(b) The 1D [Cu4L5] n chain shows that the chiral SBUs follow the order LLRR, and the adjacent homochiral SBUs (L-, L-SBUs or R-, R-SBUs) lie in two plans with an angle of 45°. (c) Three-dimensional coordination network of 1 viewed along the [0.5, 0, 0.5] direction, showing that the chains are linked by the coordination of Cl1 atoms in a 3D network (with each color representing a 1D chain and green spheres representing Cl atoms; the hydrogen atoms are omitted for clarity). (d) One-dimensional channels which are made up of opening rings (e) in 1.

(c) Three-dimensional coordination network of 1 viewed along the [0.5, 0, 0.5] direction, showing that the chains are linked by the coordination of Cl1 atoms in a 3D network (with each color representing a 1D chain and green spheres representing Cl atoms; the hydrogen atoms are omitted for clarity). elements.content: For the sake of the topological classification of 1, we have performed the analysis using ToposPro. Following the third approach as mentioned above, the four copper atoms Cu1, Cu2, Cu3, and Cu4 in any combination were chosen to act as central atoms, but the classical topology could not be obtained yet. Considering the important connection function of N2, O1, and Cl1 for structure configuration, these three atoms were selected and acted as central atoms, resulting in a rare uninodal (n1) sra (42, 63, 8) topology with three connections of a1, b1, and c1 ().
elements.clean_text:
Topology Analysis

For the sake of the topological classification of 1, we have performed the analysis using ToposPro. Following the third approach as mentioned above, the four copper atoms Cu1, Cu2, Cu3, and Cu4 in any combination were chosen to act as central atoms, but the classical topology could not be obtained yet. Considering the important connection function of N2, O1, and Cl1 for structure configuration, these three atoms were selected and acted as central atoms, resulting in a rare uninodal (n1) sra (42, 63, 8) topology with three connections of a1, b1, and c1 ().

elements.content: Schematic illustration of (a) the uninodal topologies of sra (42, 63, 8) for complex 1. (b) The result of running ADS, shows that the nodes are linked by central atoms of O1 (red spheres), N2 (blue spheres), and Cl1 (green spheres), and the corresponding relationship for connections of a1, b1, and c1 with central atoms/connecting atoms of N1, O1, and Cl1, respectively. (c) Chain viewed along the c axis and (d) chain viewed along the b axis showing the united node [Cu4L5] of sra and connections a1 and b1 within the chain.

(b) The result of running ADS, shows that the nodes are linked by central atoms of O1 (red spheres), N2 (blue spheres), and Cl1 (green spheres), and the corresponding relationship for connections of a1, b1, and c1 with central atoms/connecting atoms of N1, O1, and Cl1, respectively. (c) Chain viewed along the c axis and (d) chain viewed along the b axis showing the united node [Cu4L5] of sra and connections a1 and b1 within the chain.

elements.content: The correlation between the topology and the structure was investigated through the result of running ADS software. As shown in b, it provides structural information of node n1, central atom Cl1, and N2 atoms, which proves that node n1 is located in the center of R/L-[Cu4L5] (c,d); therefore, R/L-[Cu4L5] is the structural unit node of sra. The connections of a1, b1, and c1 correspond to the distances between adjacent nodes linked by N2, O1, and Cl1, respectively. Moreover, because the nodes are doubly connected by two atoms of N2/O1 within the chain, the topology type forms the chain-based sra-net (c,d). For chain-based topology, the nodes usually occupy short multiconnections within the chain. It should be noticed that the topology analysis is based just on connection atoms of O1, N2, and Cl1 as central atoms, which is conceptually different from the current analytical methods which are based on node atoms as central atoms.

elements.content: In this regard, O1 and Cl1 as direct linking atoms for adjacent structural units of LR-[Cu4L5]2 were selected to serve as central atoms in the topology calculation process by TopoPro, thereby achieving the topology with the node of LR-[Cu4L5]2. A classic uninodal pcu (412, 63) topology with two connections of a2 and b2 was obtained, as shown in a. According to the ADS software analysis (b), node n2 is located in the center of structural unit LR-[Cu4L5]2, which is the structural unit node of pcu (412, 63) (c,d). The connections of a2 and b2 correspond to the adjacent nodes linked by O1 and Cl1, respectively. Because the units of LR-[Cu4L5]2 are doubly linked by two O1 atoms in the chain as well, this topology type is also chain-based pcu-net.

elements.content: For the next step, N2 and Cl1 were chosen to act as the central atoms in the topology analysis, leading to a uninodal dia (66) topology with two connections of a3 and b3 (a). The ADS results verified that RR-[Cu4L5]2 and LL-[Cu4L5]2 are the structural united nodes of dia (66) (b). RR-[Cu4L5]2 and LL-[Cu4L5]2 are doubly linked by two carboxyl N2 atoms, which also make them a chain-based dia-net (c,d). The connections of a3 and b3 represent the length between two nodes linked by N2 and Cl1 atoms, respectively. Hence, N2 and Cl1 are also the connection atoms of the dia-net.

The ADS results verified that RR-[Cu4L5]2 and LL-[Cu4L5]2 are the structural united nodes of dia (66) (b). RR-[Cu4L5]2 and LL-[Cu4L5]2 are doubly linked by two carboxyl N2 atoms, which also make them a chain-based dia-net (c,d). The connections of a3 and b3 represent the length between two nodes linked by N2 and Cl1 atoms, respectively. Hence, N2 and Cl1 are also the connection atoms of the dia-net.

elements.content: Schematic representation of (a) the uninodal topology of dia (66). (b) The result of running ADS shows that the nodes are linked by central atoms of N2 (blue spheres) and Cl1 (green spheres) as well as the corresponding relationship for connections of a3 and b3 with central atoms/connection atoms of N2 and Cl1, respectively. (c) The chain viewed along the b axis and (d) the chain viewed along the c axis show two units of R-[Cu4L5]/L-[Cu4L5] linked by an N2 atom forming RR-[Cu4L5]2/LL-[Cu4L5]2 as nodes of dia and also show that the connection of a3 is the distance between two nodes within the chain (blue line).

elements.content: Such analysis inspired us to try out the possibilities for all the other atoms of μ3-L. Choosing C1/C7 and Cl1 as central atoms in the calculation also gave the dia (66) topology when selecting N2 and Cl1. In addition, using atoms of C1/C7, O1, and Cl as central atoms produced the sra (42, 63, 8) topology by employing N2, O1, and Cl1 ( and S2–S8). Therefore, substituting C1/C7 for the N2 atom results in the same topologies, but attempts to choose other uncoordinated atoms of μ3-L for the analysis did not result in suitable topology.

The success of topology analysis based on the choice of connection atoms as central atoms is attributed to complex 1’s architectural features. All coordination centers in 1 are directly connected by O1 (Cu2–O1–Cu4) and Cl1 (Cu1–Cl1–Cu3), leading O1 and Cl1 to be the key connection atoms in the whole network. The μ3-L ligand containing O1 is also viewed as a significant linker. In addition, Cl, C7, and N2 possess better connectivity than other atoms on the μ3-L ligand. Overall, O1, Cl1, N2, C1, and C7 can all be applicable to act as central atoms in the analysis. These topologies with large nodes and short connections clearly reveal the details of the connections between the chains. These nodes of L/R-[Cu4L5], LR-[Cu4L5]2, and LL/RR-[Cu4L5]2, as different parts of the chain, provide link modes of (42, 63, 8), (412, 63), and (66), respectively (, a, a, and a).

elements.content: To characterize the valence of copper, X-ray photoelectron spectroscopy (XPS) was applied to study complex 1. The wide-scan XPS spectra of 1 is shown in Figure S3: the predominant peaks observed are O 1s, C 1s, N 1s, and Cu 2p. In b, the Cu 2p core-level spectrum of 1 is shown to demostrate the existance of mixed valence. It is clear that the spectra exhibit two main peaks at binding energies (BEs) of about 931 and 934 eV, respectively, in 1. The presence of 934 eV is representative of the +2 oxidation state for the Cu 2p3/2 orbital, while 931 eV represents the oxidation state of +1. Thus, the XPS spectra provide evidence that CuI and CuII exist in 1.
elements.clean_text:
XPS Analysis

To characterize the valence of copper, X-ray photoelectron spectroscopy (XPS) was applied to study complex 1. The wide-scan XPS spectra of 1 is shown in Figure S3: the predominant peaks observed are O 1s, C 1s, N 1s, and Cu 2p. In b, the Cu 2p core-level spectrum of 1 is shown to demostrate the existance of mixed valence. It is clear that the spectra exhibit two main peaks at binding energies (BEs) of about 931 and 934 eV, respectively, in 1. The presence of 934 eV is representative of the +2 oxidation state for the Cu 2p3/2 orbital, while 931 eV represents the oxidation state of +1. Thus, the XPS spectra provide evidence that CuI and CuII exist in 1.

elements.content: The powder X-ray diffraction first proved the purity of complex 1 by comparing the sample with the simulated PXRD pattern of 1 (Figure S4). The thermogravimetric analysis (Figure S5) and variable-temperature PXRD (Figure S6) studies show that 1 can be readily activated while maintaining the structural integrity of the frameworks with high thermostability up to 460 °C under an N2 atmosphere. To examine the permanent porosities and storage capability, the gas adsorption properties of desolvated 1 were investigated. Interestingly, unique behaviors have been shown in . The adsorption/desorption isotherms of 1 reveal that almost no adsorption was observed for N2 at 77 K. However, the CO2 adsorption/desorption isotherms of 1 at 195 K exhibit type I behavior, and the maximum CO2 uptake is up to 82 cm3·g–1 at 195 K and 1.0 atm, which is higher than for other porous CPs with similar void volumes. Furthermore, the noncoordinated carboxyl oxygen and thiazolyl sulfur atoms of the ligand can provide interaction sites with CO2 and enhance the CO2 adsorption capacity. This suggests that the selective sorption of CO2 over N2 for desolvated 1 may be attributed to the host–guest interactions rather than the different dynamic diameters of CO2 (3.30 Å) and N2 (3.64 Å).

Adsorption Property

The powder X-ray diffraction first proved the purity of complex 1 by comparing the sample with the simulated PXRD pattern of 1 (Figure S4). The thermogravimetric analysis (Figure S5) and variable-temperature PXRD (Figure S6) studies show that 1 can be readily activated while maintaining the structural integrity of the frameworks with high thermostability up to 460 °C under an N2 atmosphere. To examine the permanent porosities and storage capability, the gas adsorption properties of desolvated 1 were investigated. Interestingly, unique behaviors have been shown in . The adsorption/desorption isotherms of 1 reveal that almost no adsorption was observed for N2 at 77 K. However, the CO2 adsorption/desorption isotherms of 1 at 195 K exhibit type I behavior, and the maximum CO2 uptake is up to 82 cm3⋅g-1 at 195 K and 1.0 atm, which is higher than for other porous CPs with similar void volumes. Furthermore, the noncoordinated carboxyl oxygen and thiazolyl sulfur atoms of the ligand can provide interaction sites with CO2 and enhance the CO2 adsorption capacity. This suggests that the selective sorption of CO2 over N2 for desolvated 1 may be attributed to the host-guest interactions rather than the different dynamic diameters of CO2 (3.30 Å) and N2 (3.64 Å).

elements.content: Topology analysis for a four-copper-center MOF [Cu8Cl2(ptca)10·17H2O] n (1) using ToposPro led to three chain-based topology types, sra (42, 63, 8), pcu (412, 63) and dia (66), by changing the connection atoms as central atoms, even for nonmetallic atoms. The connection atoms which directly associate with multiple coordination centers are applicable to act as central atoms. Moreover, topology, as the expression of a repeated rule of nodes, has no limit on node size and linker length and is essential to the structural analysis of complex complexes. In addition, complex 1 has meaningful selective sorption of CO2 over N2. This research broadens the methodology of topology analysis and deepens the understanding of the topology concept, which will potentially guide future topology analysis.
elements.clean_text:
Conclusions

Topology analysis for a four-copper-center MOF [Cu8Cl2(ptca)10⋅17H2O] n  (1) using ToposPro led to three chain-based topology types, sra (42, 63, 8), pcu (412, 63) and dia (66), by changing the connection atoms as central atoms, even for nonmetallic atoms. The connection atoms which directly associate with multiple coordination centers are applicable to act as central atoms. Moreover, topology, as the expression of a repeated rule of nodes, has no limit on node size and linker length and is essential to the structural analysis of complex complexes. In addition, complex 1 has meaningful selective sorption of CO2 over N2. This research broadens the methodology of topology analysis and deepens the understanding of the topology concept, which will potentially guide future topology analysis.

It was held at 120 °C for 2 days. After it cooled to room temperature, yellow block crystals of complex 1 were obtained in 58% yield. The resulting solution had a pH value of 7. Anal. cln_elements.content: Schematic illustration of (a) the levorotatory and dextrorotatory SBUs of [Cu4L5] in 1. (b) The 1D [Cu4L5] n chain shows that the chiral SBUs follow the order LLRR, and the adjacent homochiral SBUs (L-, L-SBUs or R-, R-SBUs) lie in two plans with an angle of 45°. (c) Three-dimensional coordination network of 1 viewed along the [0.5, 0, 0.5] direction, showing that the chains are linked by the coordination of Cl1 atoms in a 3D network (with each color representing a 1D chain and green spheres representing Cl atoms; the hydrogen atoms are omitted for clarity). (d) One-dimensional channels which are made up of opening rings (e) in 1.
cln_elements.clean_text: 1  Schematic illustration of (a) the levorotatory and dextrorotatory SBUs of [Cu4L5] in 1. (b) The 1D [Cu4L5] n  chain shows that the chiral SBUs follow the order LLRR, and the adjacent homochiral SBUs (L-, L-SBUs or R-, R-SBUs) lie in two plans with an angle of 45°. (c) Three-dimensional coordination network of 1 viewed along the [0.5, 0, 0.5] direction, showing that the chains are linked by the coordination of Cl1 atoms in a 3D network (with each color representing a 1D chain and green spheres representing Cl atoms; the hydrogen atoms are omitted for clarity). (d) One-dimensional channels which are made up of opening rings (e) in 1.

cln_elements.content: Schematic illustration of (a) the uninodal topologies of sra (42, 63, 8) for complex 1. (b) The result of running ADS, shows that the nodes are linked by central atoms of O1 (red spheres), N2 (blue spheres), and Cl1 (green spheres), and the corresponding relationship for connections of a1, b1, and c1 with central atoms/connecting atoms of N1, O1, and Cl1, respectively. (c) Chain viewed along the c axis and (d) chain viewed along the b axis showing the united node [Cu4L5] of sra and connections a1 and b1 within the chain.
cln_elements.clean_text: 2  Schematic illustration of (a) the uninodal topologies of sra (42, 63, 8) for complex 1. (b) The result of running ADS, shows that the nodes are linked by central atoms of O1 (red spheres), N2 (blue spheres), and Cl1 (green spheres), and the corresponding relationship for connections of a1, b1, and c1 with central atoms/connecting atoms of N1, O1, and Cl1, respectively. (c) Chain viewed along the c axis and (d) chain viewed along the b axis showing the united node [Cu4L5] of sra and connections a1 and b1 within the chain.

cln_elements.content: Schematic representation of (a) the uninodal topology of pcu (412, 63). (b) The result of running ADS shows that the nodes are linked by central atoms of O1 (red spheres) and Cl1 (green spheres) as well as the corresponding relationship for connections of a2 and b2 with central atoms/connection atoms of O1 and Cl1, respectively. (c) Chain viewed along the b axis showing node LR-[Cu4L5]2 of pcu and the connection of a1 (blue line), (d) node LR-[Cu4L5]2 viewed along the extension direction of chain [0.5 0 0.5], and (e) the network of 1 viewed along the direction of [0.5 0 0.5] showing the nodes linked by Cl atoms and the connection of b2 (green line).
cln_elements.clean_text: 3  Schematic representation of (a) the uninodal topology of pcu (412, 63). (b) The result of running ADS shows that the nodes are linked by central atoms of O1 (red spheres) and Cl1 (green spheres) as well as the corresponding relationship for connections of a2 and b2 with central atoms/connection atoms of O1 and Cl1, respectively. (c) Chain viewed along the b axis showing node LR-[Cu4L5]2 of pcu and the connection of a1 (blue line), (d) node LR-[Cu4L5]2 viewed along the extension direction of chain [0.5 0 0.5], and (e) the network of 1 viewed along the direction of [0.5 0 0.5] showing the nodes linked by Cl atoms and the connection of b2 (green line).

cln_elements.content: Schematic representation of (a) the uninodal topology of dia (66). (b) The result of running ADS shows that the nodes are linked by central atoms of N2 (blue spheres) and Cl1 (green spheres) as well as the corresponding relationship for connections of a3 and b3 with central atoms/connection atoms of N2 and Cl1, respectively. (c) The chain viewed along the b axis and (d) the chain viewed along the c axis show two units of R-[Cu4L5]/L-[Cu4L5] linked by an N2 atom forming RR-[Cu4L5]2/LL-[Cu4L5]2 as nodes of dia and also show that the connection of a3 is the distance between two nodes within the chain (blue line).
